'''SolarCity Corporation''' is a subsidiary of [[Tesla, Inc.]] that specializes in [[solar energy]] services and is headquartered in [[San Mateo, California]].
SolarCity markets, manufactures, and installs residential and commercial solar panels and solar roofs in the US. In 2016, the company was acquired by [[Tesla, Inc.]] and now also offers energy storage services through Tesla, including a turnkey residential battery backup service that incorporates Tesla's [[Tesla Powerwall|Powerwall]]. The company, in partnership with [[Panasonic]], operates [[Giga New York|Tesla Giga New York]], a factory in [[Buffalo, New York]], where it manufactures solar module components.
==History== {{Multiple image | direction = vertical | align = right | width = 220 | image1 = 393 Vintage Park Drive, Foster City.JPG | image2 = Pair of 2009 SolarCity Dodge Sprinters.JPG | image3 = SolarCity vehicle.jpg | caption1 = Original SolarCity headquarters in [[Foster City, California]] | caption2 = Installation vehicles with the original SolarCity logo | caption3 = SolarCity vehicle with current SolarCity logo at night }}
SolarCity was founded in 2006 by brothers Peter and [[Lyndon Rive]],<ref name="time20080417">[http://content.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1730759_1730843_1730983,00.html Solarcity] ''Time Magazine'', April 17, 2008.</ref> based on a suggestion for a solar company concept by their cousin, [[Elon Musk]], who was the chairman and helped start the company.<ref>[http://news.cnet.com/Elon-Musk-on-rockets,-sports-cars,-and-solar-power---page-2/2008-11389_3-6230661-2.html Newsmaker: Elon Musk on rockets, sports cars and solar power], ''news.cnet.com'', Michael Kanellos, February 15, 2008.</ref> By 2009, solar panels it had installed were capable of generating 440 [[megawatt]]s (MW) of power.<ref name=SEIAdata>{{cite web |url= https://www.seia.org/solar-industry-research-data|title= Solar Industry Data; Solar Industry Breaks 20 GW Barrier - Grows 34% Over 2013|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2015|website= SEAI Research & Resources|publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association|access-date= 29 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Solar Installer Sues for U.S. Grant Funds|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324582004578457431235673210 |accessdate=2013-08-11 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=2013-05-06 |first1=Cassandra |last1=Sweet |first2=Ryan |last2=Tracy}}</ref>

web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/sbo/2011/01/solarcity-buys-clean-currents.html|title=SolarCity buys Clean Currents|last=|first=|date=Jan 24, opened in Connecticut<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.courant.com/business/hc-xpm-2012-02-07-hc-solar-city-expands-20120207-story.html|title=SolarCity, Solar Panel Company, Establishes Hartford Office|last=PODSADA|first=JANICE|website=courant.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-02-26}}</ref>, Pennsylvania<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/business/powersource/2016/11/04/Solar-City-eyeing-growth-in-Pittsburgh-region-opens-operations-center/stories/201611040063|title=Solar City, eyeing growth in Pittsburgh region, opens operations center|website=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|language=en|access-date=2019-03-01}}</ref>, South Carolina<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2016/10/06/solarcity-expands-services-south-carolina/|website=[[cleantechnica.com]]|access-date=2019-03-01|title=SolarCity expands services into South Carolina}}</ref>, Florida<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/technology/tech_check/os-solar-city-florida-expansion-20161201-story.html|title=Elon Musk's SolarCity expanding in Clermont|last=Santana|first=Marco|website=OrlandoSentinel.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-01}}</ref>, Vermont<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vermontbiz.com/news/august/solarcity-launches-new-solar-loan-program-vermont|title=SolarCity launches new solar loan program in Vermont|date=2016-08-06|website=Vermont Business Magazine|language=en|access-date=2019-03-01}}</ref>, and New Hampshire.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhpr.org/post/solar-energy-giant-move-nh-market|title=Solar Energy Giant To Move Into N.H. Market|last=Evans-Brown|first=Sam|website=www.nhpr.org|language=en|access-date=2019-03-01}}</ref>
In 2013, SolarCity was the leading residential solar installer in the U.S.<ref>[https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/is-the-solarcity-model-the-only-way-to-scale-residential-solar Is the SolarCity Model the Only Way to Scale Residential Solar?], ''greentechmedia.com'', Nicole Litvak, March 31, 2014.</ref> Solar Power World magazine listed it as the No. 2 overall solar installation company in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/top-250-solar-contractors/ |title=2013 Top 250 Solar Contractors|work=Solar Power World|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref> In 2013, SolarCity purchased Paramount Solar from [[Paramount Equity]] for $120 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://solarindustrymag.com/solarcity-completes-acquisition-of-paramount-solar |title=SolarCity Completes Acquisition of Paramount Solar|publisher= |date=11 September 2013|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> By 2014, it had installed panels capable of generating 6,200 MW of power.<ref name=SEIAdata/> In 2015, SolarCity installed 870MW of solar power,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.solarcity.com/sites/default/files/SolarCity_Impact_Report_2015.pdf |title=SolarCity 2015 Impact Report}}</ref> approximately 28% of non-utility solar installation in the U.S. that year.<ref name=SEIAdata/>
In October 2014, SolarCity announced it would be offering up to $200 million in solar bonds to launch a new online website to buy the debt, the first registered public offering of such bonds in the [[United States]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/15/us-solarcity-bonds-idUSKCN0I41KO20141015 SolarCity offers $200 million solar bonds in first public offering]. [[Reuters]], 16 October 2014</ref> In March 2016, [[SpaceX]] bought $90 million of SolarCity stock.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investors.solarcity.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1564590-16-15105&CIK=1408356 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330071152/http://investors.solarcity.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1564590-16-15105&CIK=1408356 |url-status=dead |archive-date=30 March 2016 |title=SolarCity - Current Report |accessdate=1 August 2016 }}</ref>
In late 2015, SolarCity withdrew from solar sales and installation in Nevada, following the decision by the state's Public Utilities Commission (PUC) to raise the monthly service charge for rooftop solar customers and progressively reduce the return on solar energy sold back into the grid under the state's [[net metering]] rule.<ref name="Whaley2016">{{cite news|last1=Whaley|first1=Sean|title=SolarCity cuts 550 Nevada jobs, blames new net metering rate |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/solarcity-cuts-550-nevada-jobs-blames-new-net-metering-rate|accessdate=30 May 2016|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=6 January 2016}}</ref> Under the new rules, the monthly service charge imposed on Nevada Power's rooftop solar-generating customers rose from $12.75 to $17.90, and was scheduled to rise to $38.51 by January 1, 2020; simultaneously, the rates given to rooftop solar generating customers for their surplus solar energy were also clawed back and were to continue to decline over the ensuing four years.<ref name="Whaley2016"/> As a result, SolarCity eliminated more than 550 jobs in Nevada.<ref name="Whaley2016"/>
In June 2016, Musk's car and battery company, [[Tesla Inc.|Tesla]], submitted an offer to acquire SolarCity for $2.5–3 billion.<ref name=TM2016-06-22>{{cite web|url=https://www.teslamotors.com/blog/tesla-makes-offer-to-acquire-solarcity |title=Tesla Makes Offer to Acquire SolarCity|website=www.teslamotors.com |access-date=2016-06-22}}</ref> According to Musk, the reason for this is "Creating a seamlessly integrated Tesla battery & solar power product that looks beautiful".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/752218264499949568?lang=en |title=Elon Musk on Twitter|date=10 July 2016 |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref> On August 1, 2016, SolarCity accepted Tesla Motors' offer of $2.6 billion. The merger was completed later in 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lienert|first1=Paul|title=SolarCity accepts Tesla's $2.6 billion offer; both shares fall|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-solarcity-m-a-tesla-idUSKCN10C26O |accessdate=1 August 2016|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref name=closing>{{cite web |url=http://ir.tesla.com/secfiling.cfm?filingid=1193125-16-773705&CIK=1318605 |title=Tesla - Current Report |access-date=2016-11-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620024603/http://ir.tesla.com/secfiling.cfm?filingid=1193125-16-773705&CIK=1318605 |archive-date=2018-06-20 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
===2016 workforce reduction=== In 2015, the number of employees had grown by 68.7%.<ref name=":4"/> At the end of 2015, SolarCity had 15,273 employees; at the end of 2016, it had 12,243 employees.<ref name=":3"/> SolarCity eliminated 20% of its total workforce in 2016.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://buffalonews.com/2017/03/02/solarcity-cut-20-percent-jobs-last-year/|title=SolarCity, gearing up to begin work here, cut 3,000 jobs in 2016|last=Robinson|first=David|date=2017-03-02|website=The Buffalo News|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref> The company did so to preserve cash.<ref name=":6">{{cite news|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/Business/2017/0302/SolarCity-s-workforce-shrinks-but-predictions-for-solar-point-up|title=SolarCity's workforce shrinks – but predictions for solar point up|last=Rosen|first=Ben|date=2017-03-02|work=Christian Science Monitor|access-date=2017-03-02|issn=0882-7729}}</ref> The job cuts affected workers across the entire company:<ref name=":3"/><ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://fortune.com/2017/03/02/tesla-solarcity-staff-cuts-2016/|title=Tesla's SolarCity Cut 20% of Its Staff Last Year|last=|first=|date=2017-03-02|website=Fortune|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref> 22% of jobs were cut in operations, installations, and manufacturing; 27% in sales and marketing. 2016 was the first year in the company's history that SolarCity cut its workforce.<ref name=":5">{{cite news|url=https://madison.com/business/investment/markets-and-stocks/why-tesla-had-to-lay-off-solarcity-employees/article_a30429dd-8a45-59d2-8d83-7a10d5aa54ab.html|title=Why Tesla Had to Lay Off 3,000 SolarCity Employees |date=2017-03-02 |work=Madison.com|access-date=2017-03-02|language=en}}</ref>
In August 2016, it was announced that the company planned to take up $5 million in charges to cover its planned layoffs. The company also cut the salaries of its two co-founders from $275,000 to $1 per year.<ref>Allana Akhtar, WGRZ. "[https://www.wgrz.com/article/news/local/solarcity-announces-layoffs-cuts-executive-pay-to-1/303248481 SolarCity announces layoffs, cuts executive pay to $1]." August 19, 2016. August 23, 2016.</ref>
===Subsidiary of Tesla Inc. (2016–present)=== On August 1, 2016, Tesla announced in a joint statement with SolarCity it would be acquiring the company in an all-stock $2.6 billion merger. Tesla's mission since its inception has been "to accelerate the world's transition to sustainable energy".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-the-future-of-tesla-could-look-like-2018-4|title=Here's what the future of Tesla could look like|last=Desjardins|first=Jeff|date=28 April 2018|work=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=22 January 2020|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501203935/https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-the-future-of-tesla-could-look-like-2018-4|archivedate=1 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As part of Elon Musk's "The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan", Tesla sought to expedite the world's move from a mine-and-burn hydrocarbon economy towards a solar electric economy.<ref name=MasterPlan>{{cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |url=https://www.tesla.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |title=The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan (just between you and me) No. 124 |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=2006-08-02 |accessdate=2010-10-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802142703/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |archive-date=2010-08-02 |url-status=live}}{{Self-published source|inline |date=May 2015}}</ref> The announcement cited operational and cost "synergies", and integrated products that would be realized with the acquisition. The action was approved by antitrust regulators.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tesla Has Won Antitrust Approval to Buy SolarCity |url=https://fortune.com/2016/08/25/tesla-solarcity-antitrust-approval/ |date=August 25, 2016|accessdate=2016-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tesla and SolarCity confirm merger in $2.6BN stock deal |url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-and-solarcity-merger/ |date=August 1, 2016|accessdate=2016-08-01}}</ref> {{As of|2016|08}}, Musk owned 22% of SolarCity stock.<ref name="lat20160721">{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-musk-master-plan-20160714-snap-story.html |title=Tesla's stock falls after Elon Musk reveals his 'master plan' |first=Russ|last=Mitchell |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=21 July 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref> More than 85% of unaffiliated shareholders from Tesla and SolarCity voted to approve the acquisition on November 17, 2016,<ref name="Tesla's Acquisition of SolarCity Receives Shareholder Approval">{{cite web|title= Tesla’s Acquisition of SolarCity Receives Shareholder Approval|url=https://www.tesla.com/en_GB/blog/teslas-acquisition-of-solarcity-receives-shareholder-approval |accessdate=2016-11-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2016/11/17/early-christmas-present-for-elon-musk-as-shareholders-bless-tesla-solarcity-merger/ |title=Early Christmas Present For Elon Musk As Shareholders Bless Tesla-SolarCity Merger|date=17 November 2016|work=Forbes|accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> which was closed on the morning of November 21, 2016.
Some investors criticized the deal, calling it "a misguided effort to rescue two companies that depend on investors and the government for operating cash."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-shareholder-vote-tesla-solarcity-musk-20161012-snap-story.html|title=Shareholders to vote on Tesla-SolarCity merger next month|date=2016-10-12|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref> There is ongoing litigation against Musk and Tesla's board of directors, alleging "they overpaid for SolarCity, ignored their own conflicts of interest and failed to disclose 'troubling facts' essential to a rational analysis of the proposed deal."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2019-09-23/solarcity-tesla-merger-shareholder-lawsuit|title=Elon Musk knew SolarCity was going broke before merger with Tesla, lawsuit alleges|date=2019-09-24|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/23/tesla-solarcity-claims-detailed-in-newly-unsealed-court-docs.html|title=Tesla and Musk hid facts about SolarCity deal and SpaceX involvement, shareholders claim in unsealed court docs|last=Kolodny|first=Lora|date=2019-09-23|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref> Musk unveiled a new solar roof tile in October 2016 in order to gain investor support for the acquisition.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2019-09-23/solarcity-tesla-merger-shareholder-lawsuit|title=Elon Musk knew SolarCity was going broke before merger with Tesla, lawsuit alleges|date=2019-09-24|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref> However, the tile on display later turned out to be fake.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/28/musk-deposition-stockholders-v-tesla-solarcity.html|title=Tesla's Elon Musk knew SolarCity faced a 'liquidity crisis' at time of 2016 deal, legal documents show|last=Kolodny|first=Lora|date=2019-10-28|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref> As of June 2019, "the company's solar roof tiles were not yet functional."<ref name=":13" />
Tesla's 2017 goals were to launch a new car, open a large battery factory, and "perfect autonomous driving". In November 2016 Musk called the merger a "no-brainer" for SolarCity. He said that it was an accident of history that Tesla and SolarCity were two separate companies before the acquisition.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.marketwatch.com/story/elon-musk-plans-crazy-2017-for-tesla-but-solarcity-may-be-the-biggest-headache-2016-12-22 |title=Elon Musk plans crazy 2017 for Tesla, but SolarCity may be the biggest headache|last=Assis|first=Claudia |date=2016-12-28 |work=|newspaper=MarketWatch |language=en-US|access-date= 2017-01-20|via=}}</ref> Lyndon Rive left SolarCity in June 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-solar-rive-idUSKCN18B2RP |title=Former SolarCity CEO Lyndon Rive will leave Tesla|date=15 May 2017|publisher= |accessdate=16 May 2017|via=Reuters}}</ref> and Peter Rive left shortly thereafter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-rive-is-leaving-tesla-solarcity-lyndon-rive-2017-7|title=SolarCity cofounder Peter Rive is leaving Tesla months after multibillion acquisition|last=Logan|first=Bryan|date=Jul 18, 2017|website=Business Insider|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-04-19}}</ref> The chief policy officer of SolarCity, John Wellinghoff, left SolarCity in April 2017.<ref name="Shallenberger-UtilityDive">{{cite news|last1=Shallenberger |first1=Krysti |title=Former FERC chair Jon Wellinghoff no longer at SolarCity|url=https://www.utilitydive.com/news/former-ferc-chair-jon-wellinghoff-no-longer-at-solarcity/441213/|accessdate=26 April 2017|work=Utility Dive|date=25 April 2017}}</ref> [[Gigafactory 2]] ([[Giga New York]]) opened in Buffalo in late August 2017.<ref> Fred Lambert, [[Electrek]]. "[https://electrek.co/2017/08/31/tesla-solar-cell-production-gigafactory-2-buffalo-solar-roof/ Tesla starts solar cell production at Gigafactory 2 in Buffalo, raises annual capacity goal to 2 GW]." Aug 31, 2017. Retrieved May 21, 2018. </ref>
Total solar installations have been declining since the Tesla acquisition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-tesla-musk-revenue-sec-filing-20190430-story.html|title=Ugly turns uglier as a Tesla filing shows results were goosed by a surge in credits|date=2019-04-30|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref> Tesla's energy revenues increased from $1.12 billion in 2017 to $1.55 billion in 2018, but declined slightly in 2019 to $1.53 billion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000156459020004475/0001564590-20-004475-index.htm|title=EDGAR Filing Documents for 0001564590-20-004475|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2020-01-29/tesla-earnings-musk|title=Tesla reports a fourth-quarter profit, and its stock soars again|date=2020-01-29|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref> Analysts believe that SolarCity has been "a big source of the cash-flow deficit" for Tesla.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/08/how-elon-musk-gambled-tesla-to-save-solarcity|title=“He’s Full of Shit”: How Elon Musk Gambled Tesla to Save SolarCity|last=McLean|first=Bethany|website=Vanity Fair|language=en|access-date=2020-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Grant|first=Charley|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/investors-helped-build-tesla-they-could-undo-it-too-11558721830|title=Investors Helped Build Tesla. They Could Undo It, Too.|date=2019-05-24|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2020-04-28|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
==Locations== Headquarters are in [[San Mateo, California|San Mateo]], [[California]], while the company uses a distributed service model in which it provides installation from local operations centers.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Nichola|last1=Groom|accessdate=2018-06-22|title=Exclusive: Tesla to close a dozen solar facilities in nine states|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-solar-exclusive/exclusive-tesla-to-close-a-dozen-solar-facilities-in-nine-states-documents-idUSKBN1JI013|newspaper=Reuters U.S.}}</ref>
As of May 2016, SolarCity operates in 20 jurisdictions: 18 states on the West Coast, in the Southwest, and in the Northeast, as well as Hawaii, and the District of Columbia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solarcity.com/residential/states|accessdate=2016-05-30|title=SolarCity locations}}</ref>
==Products, services, and technologies==
===Solar leasing=== In 2008, SolarCity entered the solar leasing market with a new solar lease option for homeowners: leasing rooftop solar to customers who would pay no upfront costs. In exchange, customers paid for 20 years for power generated by those panels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/environment/2008/04/24/solar-power-for-less-than-your-cable-bill/ |title=Solar power for less than your cable bill | Environment Forum |publisher=Blogs.reuters.com |date= 2008-04-24|accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref> SolarCity's solar lease allowed some homeowners to pay less each month than they previously paid for electricity from the utility company.<ref>{{cite web|last=Earnest |first=John |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20080927-9999-1mc27solar.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081001113917/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20080927-9999-1mc27solar.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2008-10-01 |title=Leasing a solar-power system |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2008-09-27 |accessdate=2011-10-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sistek |first=Hanna |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-9994005-54.html |title=SolarCity provides SF power below grid price | Green Tech - CNET News |publisher=News.cnet.com |date=2008-07-18 |accessdate=2011-10-15}}</ref>
The "no-money-down solar" business model became the most popular in the USA<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-24/why-lease-when-you-can-own-the-tough-question-facing-solarcity|title=Why Lease When You Can Own? Rooftop Solar Facing Tough Question|date=2016-05-24|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-15}}</ref> and increased installations, but it also added to SolarCity's debt, accounting for about half of the company's over $3 billion debt in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://buffalonews.com/2016/11/15/tesla-solarcity-merger-risky-debt/|title=Tesla-SolarCity merger: How risky is all that debt?|date=2016-11-15|work=The Buffalo News|access-date=2017-12-15|language=en-US}}</ref> Beginning in 2017 (after Tesla acquired the company) its business model shifted to one where customers buy the solar systems with cash or via financing.<ref name=":3"/> Tesla, the parent company, decided to change from selling solar products door-to-door to only being sold in Tesla's stores and galleries, which Tesla believed would save on advertising.<ref name=":6"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-solar/tesla-largely-responsible-for-slide-in-u-s-home-solar-sales-report-idUSKBN1E915A|title=Tesla largely responsible for slide in U.S. home solar sales: report|last=|first=|date=2017-12-15|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-12-15}}</ref> In June 2018, Elon Musk announced that Tesla would be pulling out of their solar sales partnership with Home Depot four months after national kickoff, initially aimed at growing sales of Tesla's solar and storage products.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/06/12/tesla-pulls-plug-home-depot-solar-sales-four-months-after-kickoff/696101002/</ref> On February 28, 2019, Elon Musk announced that the ===Government-funded collaboration=== The SunShot Initiative is a national effort to support solar energy adoption to make solar energy affordable for all Americans. It is run by the US Department of Energy's Solar Energy Technologies Office and funds research, development, demonstration, and deployment projects. It is a collaboration of private companies, universities, state and local governments, and nonprofits, as well as national laboratories. The program began in 2011 with the initial goal of making solar energy competitive with traditional forms of electricity by 2020. By 2016, the program achieved 70% of the progress towards the 2020 goal.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://energy.gov/eere/sunshot/about-sunshot-initiative |title=About the SunShot Initiative {{!}} Department of Energy|website=energy.gov |language=en |access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20170211131857/http://energy.gov/eere/sunshot/about-sunshot-initiative -->
In the fiscal year 2012 Congressional budget, the program was appropriated $457 million. According to the US Department of Energy's appropriation request for that year, "The program also encourages Systems Integration by developing ''radically new approaches'' to reduce the cost and improve reliability and functionality of power electronics and supporting industry development through test and evaluation standards, and tools for understanding grid integration issues."<ref>[https://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/12/f5/eere_fy2012_appropriations_overview.pdf "Overview: Appropriation by Program"]. Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy. U.S. Department of Energy. Retrieved 2017-02-14.</ref><!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20170215034130/https://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/12/f5/eere_fy2012_appropriations_overview.pdf -->
SolarCity was involved in a collaboration with the program along with the Energy Department's [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] and [[Hawaiian Electric Industries]]. Using government and taxpayer funds, SolarCity helped 2,500 Hawaii residential customers connect their solar power systems to the grid by the end of December 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://energy.gov/eere/success-stories/articles/eere-success-story-sunshot-funded-advanced-inverter-testing-enables |title=EERE Success Story—SunShot-funded Advanced Inverter Testing Enables 2,500 Solar Energy Systems to Connect to Hawaii’s Electric Grid|website=Energy.gov |language=en |access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref><!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20170215034119/https://energy.gov/eere/success-stories/articles/eere-success-story-sunshot-funded-advanced-inverter-testing-enables -->
==Litigation and investigations==
===Buffalo Billion=== [[Buffalo Billion]] is a billion-dollar program from the administration of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo to revitalize Buffalo, New York. One of the main features of the program is a 1.2 million square foot solar panel factory called SolarCity RiverBend. It will be owned by SolarCity. The factory "is expected to become the largest manufacturing facility in the Western Hemisphere when it opens". Hiring for the factory is expected in spring of 2017 and the factory is expected to begin producing solar cells by the summer of 2017.<ref name=":8">{{cite news |url=https://dailyenergyinsider.com/featured/3905-success-buffalo-billion-backed-solarcity-factory-remains-elusive/|title=Success of Buffalo Billion-backed SolarCity factory remains elusive|last=Riley|first=Kim|date=2017-03-24|work=Daily Energy Insider|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
The factory will be located in an "innovation hub" called the High-Tech Manufacturing Innovation Hub at RiverBend. The state appropriated $750 million in funding for the hub. According to ''Daily Energy Insider'', "The facility will have one [[watt#Gigawatt|gigawatt]] of annual solar capacity when it reaches full production and is expected to produce about 10,000 [[solar panel]]s per day." SolarCity is required to spend $5 billion over the next decade on the facility and create more than 1,460 direct manufacturing jobs.<ref name=":8"/>
As of May 2016, federal investigators were investigating how money and contracts within the Buffalo Billion program were distributed. SolarCity was a partner in the program. The company intended to open a large solar panel factory on the Buffalo River. In May 2016, New York State officials postponed the approval of almost $500 million for the SolarCity project. According to ''The New York Times'', Buffalo Billion will benefit "a tangle of well-connected players – including developers and frequent donors to the governor – who have feasted on Buffalo Billion money".<ref name=":2">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/25/nyregion/a-tangle-of-interests-behind-cuomos-1-billion-boon-for-buffalo.html|title=$1 Billion Went to Buffalo. Cuomo Donors Benefited.|last=Mckinley|first=Jesse|date=2016-05-24|last2=Yee|first2=Vivian|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref>
On April 29, 2016, then-[[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York|U.S. Attorney]] [[Preet Bharara]] (of the Southern District of New York) began an investigation into state construction projects and contracts. Buffalo Billion was a part of that investigation. Many companies have been subpoenaed, and have provided information, including SolarCity and the office of New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]]. SolarCity is not the subject or focus of the investigation, and not involved in the vendor selection or contracting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/region-state/solar-company-acknowledges-receiving-subpoena-in-federal-probe-1.11793411|title=Solar firm acknowledges subpoena in probe|last=Harrington|first=Mark|date=2016-05-12|website=Newsday|access-date=2016-05-16}}</ref>
The United States attorney's office for the Southern District of New York is leading a federal inquiry into Buffalo Billion. Prosecutors subpoenaed several state institutions who were responsible for SolarCity and other components of the Buffalo Billion project. The subpoenas sought information about how government-funded programs were awarded and what the role was of state officials who selected the winners. Cuomo has strongly defended the project noting that there has been a decrease in unemployment and an increase in spending around the Buffalo area.<ref name=":2"/>
In February, three executives who worked for LPCiminelli Development who were arrested in 2016 in a federal bid-rigging investigation motioned to have the case against them either dismissed or moved from Manhattan to Buffalo. The three men face a 14-count indictment for [[mail and wire fraud|wire fraud]] and [[bribery]] and alleged [[bid rigging]] of the SolarCity RiverBend construction contract. Additionally, five other people have been charged with related crimes. The trials will begin in late spring of 2017.<ref name=":8"/>
An Albany firm called Whitman Osterman and Hannah represented both LPCiminelli and Fort Schuyler Management Corporation, which was a subsidiary of SUNY Polytechnic that was awarded the contract to develop the site where SolarCity is being built. The governor's office said that the formal awarding of the SolarCity contract was made by Fort Schuyler on behalf of the state. On May 18, 2016, the Public Authorities Control Board delayed a meeting at which it was set to approve $485 million in new funds for SolarCity. As late as May 2016 SolarCity said that it was cooperating with federal agents who had been in contact with the company.<ref name=":2"/>
The New York state legislature plans to approve a budget by April 1, 2017 that would give $500 million more into the Buffalo Billion program. In return, the legislature wants the Cuomo administration to put more transparency into how the money is spent.<ref name=":8"/><!-- without more than this source provides, it is unclear why this is even relevant to an article on SolarCity -->
===Oregon Attorney General investigation=== On March 30, 2017, ''[[The Oregonian]]'' said that [[Campaign for Accountability]], a D.C.-based consumer advocacy group, and other groups have asked Oregon Attorney General [[Ellen Rosenblum]] to investigate solar panel sales practices<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/mar/31/solar-group-wants-oregon-ag-to-investigate-sales-p/|title=Solar: Group wants Oregon AG to investigate sales practices|last=|first=|date=2017-03-31|work=The Washington Times|access-date=2017-04-20|language=en-US}}</ref> that "are designed to trick homeowners into buying or leasing solar panels" in violation of Oregon's Unlawful Trade Practices Act.<ref name=":9">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2017/03/consumer_group_asks_state_to_i.html |title=Consumer group asks state to investigate solar companies' sales practices|last=Sickinger|first=Ted |date=2017-03-30 |work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2017-04-20|language=en-US}}</ref> According to ''The Oregonian'', the request to Rosenblum "singled out one company: California-based SolarCity. It outlined several complaints filed against the solar giant by Oregonians who claimed they'd been misled about costs, tax credits and energy savings by the company."<ref name=":9"/>
The Campaign for Accountability reviewed 58 complaints that consumers filed with the [[Oregon Department of Justice]] and said that the complaints indicated "a widespread pattern of apparent fraud and abuse by solar companies".<ref name=":9"/> The Oregon Solar Energy Industry Association, however, said that it examined the complaints and "found the numbers to be relatively low – lower than those being cited by the Campaign for Accountability".<ref name=":9"/>
==="Solar by Degree" project=== The company is involved in a case concerning Martin Shain, the lead energy consultant in a solar power project at two Oregon universities. Shain was indicted for forgery in Marion County in August 2016. He is a consultant for BacGen Technologies in Seattle, a key player in the controversial $24 million "Solar by Degree" project and is accused of "creating a phony invoice from a fictional subcontractor that was pivotal in getting nearly $12 million in tax credits from the Oregon Department of Energy".<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2016/08/consultant_to_university_solar.html|title=Consultant to university solar project charged with forgery|last=Manning|first=Jeff|date=2016-08-29|work=The Oregonian|newspaper=|access-date=2016-11-07|via=}}</ref> The project began in 2013 and was sponsored by the [[Oregon University System]]; thousands of solar panels, generating millions of kilowatts of power per year, were constructed on 21 acres on the campuses of [[Oregon State University]] and the [[Oregon Institute of Technology, Klamath Falls|Oregon Institute of Technology]] in Klamath Falls.
The state's case revolves around two documents, which include an invoice from Solar Foundations Systems dated February 25, 2011, and a December 2011 letter signed by Ryan Davies, the former head of RedCo, a Utah-based company, which was the second developer on the project. According to [[KOIN|KOIN-TV]], "The Davies letter reported $210,000 had been spent toward the project and that construction was progressing."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koin.com/2016/08/30/solar-project-consultant-charged-with-fraud-in-oregon/|title=Solar project consultant charged with fraud in Oregon|last=|first=|date=2016-08-30|website=KOIN 6|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> The Solar Foundations invoice contains details of the construction of solar arrays. The invoice was necessary to provide proof of work on the project to get tax credits from the state. The "Solar by Degree" project received the tax credits, but it was later shown that the company named on the invoice, Solar Foundations, does not exist. In addition, Davies claims he did not write nor has ever seen the RedCo letter in question and that his name was forged. Relying on this evidence, the state claims Shain forged both documents. Shain denies forging the invoice and claims it was given to him by someone else involved in the project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://washingtontimes.com/news/2016/aug/30/solar-project-consultant-charged-with-fraud-in-ore/|title=Solar project consultant charged with fraud in Oregon|last=|first=|date=2016-08-30|work=|newspaper=The Washington Times|access-date=2016-11-07|via=}}</ref> The tax credits involved were given to SolarCity, the third developer in the project, along with its financial backers. According to ''The Oregonian'', "Those backers provide upfront financing for the projects in exchange for a share of the project revenues and the federal and state tax credits, which they can use to offset their own taxes."<ref name=":0"/> SolarCity stated, "We financed and constructed the projects in accord with the requirements of the Oregon Department of Energy."<ref name=":0"/> The company argues that the state hired Shain, and it had no knowledge of the phony documents in question, otherwise it would have not pursued the endeavor.<ref name=":0"/>
===Treasury Department inquiries=== In 2012, the Treasury Department began investigative interviews of solar firms regarding their fair market value calculations for constructed solar energy systems. The IRS has yet to determine whether or not these values have been inflated. In a 2016 federal filing, SolarCity wrote, "If the Internal Revenue Service or the U.S. Treasury Department were to object to amounts we have claimed as too high of a fair market value on such systems, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and prospects." The firm stated, however, that its values were correct and complied with the Treasury Department guidelines. If the Treasury Department or IRS disagrees, SolarCity and other firms could be forced to reimburse institutions that purchase their tax credits as investments.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/lawmakers-probe-tax-incentives-received-by-solar-energy-firms-1473967056|title=Lawmakers Probe Tax Incentives Received by Solar-Energy Firms|last=Mullins|first=Brody|date=2016-09-15|last2=Dugan|first2=Ianthe Jeanne|newspaper=Wall Street Journal |issn=0099-9660|last3=Rubin|first3=Richard|access-date=2016-11-23}}</ref>
SolarCity received roughly $501.2 million in credits up until December 31, 2015. In SolarCity's 2015 annual report, a note was made stating that if the government determines misrepresentations were made, "the Department of Justice could bring a civil action to recover amounts it believes were improperly paid to us".<ref name=":1"/>
===Customer litigation=== Since 2006, SolarCity has lowered the minimum [[FICO]] score required for customers to get the leasing deals. It uses the score of 650 (a "fair" [[credit rating]]) as the cutoff. However, between 2014 and 2017, SolarCity signed long-term lease agreements with at least 14 homeowner customers right before the customers [[foreclosure|defaulted on their mortgages]]. The company has been named in 139 lawsuits where it is the defendant in legal proceedings based on "residential foreclosure action".<ref name=":7">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/22/business/solarcity-foreclosure-cases.html|title=SolarCity’s Ties to Foreclosure Cases Raise Questions on Vetting Policies|last=Ivory|first=Danielle|date=2017-02-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-17|last2=Cardwell |first2=Diane |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
In its response, SolarCity said in a statement to the ''New York Times'', "Out of more than 305,000 installed customers, SolarCity is currently involved in 139 such proceedings. The litigation is not adversarial – being named in the foreclosure proceeding provides us with advance notice that we need to reassign a contract, and many are immediately resolved with the relevant bank."<ref name=":7"/>
===Customer cancellation investigation=== The [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) began investigating [[Sunrun]] and SolarCity in May 2017, and were looking into whether they adequately disclosed canceled contracts. "Some customers say they canceled contracts after being strong-armed into solar-energy deals" and there have been hundreds of complaints to state attorneys general.<ref name=":10">{{cite news|url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/sec-probes-solar-companies-over-disclosure-of-customer-cancellations-1493803801 |title=SEC Probes Solar Companies Over Disclosure of Customer Cancellations|last=Grind|first=Kirsten |date=2017-05-03 |work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-05-05 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
The federal government is investigating whether solar companies are "masking how many customers they are losing". The SEC is involved because "investors use that cancellation metric as one way to gauge the companies' health".<ref name=":10"/> According to the ''Wall Street Journal'', "To generate business, solar companies have long relied on thousands of salespeople who knock on doors, make hundreds of cold calls and even trail people as they shop at retailers like Home Depot Inc., according to salespeople, executives and homeowners."<ref name=":10"/>
{{quote|Some customers say they were strong-armed into buying solar-energy systems by sales representatives who threatened to sue them if they didn't proceed with a project or to place a so-called mechanic's lien on their homes—a measure used to force a homeowner to pay for a home-improvement project. Others say they didn't realize they had actually signed contracts."<ref name=":10"/>}}
=== FCC receiving radio interference complaints === SolarCity installed SolarEdge inverter systems with a type of DC-DC converter called an optimizer. These systems cause radio interference as documented in April 2016 QST magazine a publication of the ARRL ( American Radio Relay League ).
===Federal settlement for allegations of False Claims Act violations=== In September 2017, as part of a legal settlement with the federal government, SolarCity agreed to pay a $29.5 million penalty regarding allegations that the company overstated the cost of facilities it developed and submitted claims for under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, which would be a violation of the False Claims Act. SolarCity dropped its lawsuit, ''Sequoia Pacific Solar I, LLC v. United States''—in which the company alleged the federal government owed it more money—as part of the settlement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.utilitydive.com/news/solarcity-to-pay-295m-to-settle-false-claims-allegations/505914/|title=SolarCity to pay $29.5M to settle false claims allegations|last=Walton|first=Robert|date=September 27, 2017|website=Utility Dive|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-31}}</ref>
As part of the settlement, the company agreed to “release all pending and future claims against the U.S. for additional payments from the grant program". The move ended a five-year investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://dailyenergyinsider.com/news/8079-teslas-solarcity-settles-alleged-fraud-claims-federal-government/|title=Tesla’s SolarCity settles alleged fraud claims with federal government|last=Riley|first=Kim|date=2017-09-25|work=Daily Energy Insider|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Vermont projects without approval=== In June 2017 the [[Vermont Public Service Board]] found that SolarCity was implementing solar projects in Vermont without approval required by law. According to Vermont Public Radio, Public Service Board Chair Anthony Roisman sent a letter to SolarCity warning the company that it needed to get regulatory approval before installing solar generation equipment and attaching it to the state's electrical grid. Roisman wrote, "Over the past few months, my office has observed a pattern of procedural issues with net-metering applications being pursued by your company." Officials at the company worked quickly to respond to the issue.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://digital.vpr.net/post/state-says-solarcity-wasnt-following-permit-process#stream/0|title=State Says SolarCity Wasn't Following Permit Process|last=Dobbs|first=Taylor|date=2017-06-30|work=Vermont Public Radio (VPR)|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en}}</ref>
===Faked sales numbers=== In July 2018, former employees filed a lawsuit against SolarCity, alleging that the corporation had approved the creation of "fake sales accounts", which resulted in an "unreasonably high valuation of SolarCity" for investors.<ref name=":11">{{cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/07/3-ex-solarcity-employees-claim-company-oversaw-bogus-sales-to-inflate-valuation/|title=Ex-SolarCity employees: We were fired after reporting millions in fake sales|last=Farivar|first=Cyrus|date=2018-07-31|work=Ars Technica|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/ex-solarcity-workers-sue-tesla-claiming-it-inflated-sales-with-fake-accounts-2018-07-31|title=Ex-SolarCity workers sue Tesla, claiming it inflated sales with fake accounts|last=Assis|first=Claudia|date=2018-08-01|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref> After informing management, including CEO Elon Musk, of these incidents, the employees were fired, which they argue contravenes California's whistleblower protection laws. A Tesla spokesman has so far denied these allegations.<ref name=":11"/>
===Walmart lawsuit=== SolarCity installed and manages solar panels on the roofs of more than 240 Walmart stores. On August 21, 2019, Walmart filed a lawsuit against Tesla, seeking reimbursement for millions of dollars in damages and release from contracts, claiming that fires on the roofs of seven of those stores since 2012 were caused by SolarCity's "negligent installation and maintenance".<ref>{{cite web|title=After seven roof fires, Walmart sues Tesla over solar panel flaws|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2019/08/after-seven-roof-fires-walmart-sues-tesla-over-solar-panel-flaws/}}</ref>
On 5 November 2019 it was announced that Walmart Inc has agreed to settle its legal dispute accusing Tesla Inc of negligence in the installation of solar panels atop hundreds of its stores, resulting in at least seven fires. A joint statement provided by Tesla stated the companies said they were "pleased to have resolved the issues raised by Walmart" concerning the installations, and looked forward to "a safe re-energization of our sustainable energy systems." Walmart had sued Tesla for breach of contract on Aug. 20 in a New York state court in Manhattan, seeking to have its solar panels removed from more than 240 stores. Walmart had accused Tesla of “widespread, systematic negligence” and ignoring prudent industry practices by relying on untrained and unsupervised personnel to install and maintain its panels, and prioritizing speed and profit over safety. Tesla's solar panel market share has been falling, prompting the Palo Alto, California-based company to cut its sales force. Revenue from Tesla's energy generation and storage operations from January to September fell 7% from a year earlier to $1.1 billion. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Walmart had no immediate additional comment. Tesla and its respective lawyers did not immediately respond to requests for comment. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-walmart-tesla-solar-lawsuit-idUSKBN1XF240|title=Tesla settles with Walmart over solar panel installations, fires|date=2019-11-05|work=Reuters|access-date=2019-11-05|language=en}}</ref>
==The Checks and Balances Project== SolarCity indirectly funds a political advocacy group known as the Checks and Balances Project. The project has criticized the elected members of the [[Arizona Corporation Commission]] (the regulatory body that oversees electricity and utilities in Arizona) for being too well-connected to utility companies. The Checks and Balances Project has filed several requests for public records from the Arizona Corporation Commission. In July 2016, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] interviewed the head of Checks and Balances as part of a larger criminal investigation into the financing of certain Arizona statewide races in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/money/business/energy/2016/07/06/fbi-questions-clean-energy-advocacy-group-az-corporation-commission-inquiry/86757378/|title=Advocacy group briefs FBI in Arizona Corporation Commission inquiry|last=|first=|date=2016-07-06|website=Arizona Republic|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref>
==Project financing and the Google Fund== SolarCity partners with banks, large corporations, and the [[asset-backed security|asset-backed]]<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1408356/000119312513424011/0001193125-13-424011-index.htm SolarCity Announces Proposed Securitization] Company press release, 4 November 2013</ref> market to create [[project finance]] funds to finance its lease and PPA ([[Power Purchase Agreement]]) options. SolarCity's financing partners have included Bank of America, Merrill Lynch, Citi, Morgan Stanley, [[National Bank of Arizona]] and U.S. Bancorp, among others.<ref name="fastcompany">{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/most-innovative-companies/2012/solarcity|title=10_SolarCity | Fast Company | Business + Innovation|publisher=fastcompany.com|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref>{{full citation needed|date=March 2013}} Among SolarCity's better-known financing partnerships was a $280 million fund created with Google to finance residential solar installations in June 2011. The Google Fund was the largest fund of its kind in the U.S., and Google's largest investment in clean energy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/06/14/technology/google_solarcity/index.htm |work=CNN |title=Google invests $280 million in SolarCity |date=2011-06-14}}</ref>
==Gigafactory 2== {{Main|Giga New York}}
